Week 5

Bhaswar Chakma

02 March 2021

Objectives

  • dplyr::Grammar of Data Manipulation
    • Five key verbs
    • Learn about data structures along the way

See https://af-ucp.courses/introR/dplyr.html for details.

dplyr

Grammar of Data Manipulation

Five Verbs:

  1. select() picks variables based on their names.
  2. mutate() adds new variables that are functions of existing variables
  3. filter() picks cases based on their values.
  4. summarise() reduces multiple values down to a single summary.
  5. arrange() changes the ordering of the rows.

Before we discover how these verbs work, please fill out the form:

  • 3.30 pm class
  • 5 pm class

Example

Data: Click here to download or check in Teams/Files.

Prepare Data

Step 1: Create/Open RStudio Project

Step 2: Read the Excel file w5-simple.xlsx; store it as df_simple

library(dplyr)
library(readxl)
df_simple <- read_excel("data/w5/w5-simple.xlsx")
df_simple
Name Age Gender Course Grade Born In the U.S.A.
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE

Step 3: Rename

Use rename() and the pipe operator %>%

Keyboard shortcut for %>%:

  • Windows: Ctrl+Shift+M
  • Mac: Cmd+Shift+M
df_simple <- df_simple %>% 
  rename(name = Name,
         age = Age,
         gender = Gender,
         course = Course,
         grade = Grade,
         us_born = "Born In the U.S.A.")
df_simple
name age gender course grade us_born
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE

select()

Problem: Suppose we want to drop the variable course

Solution:

  • We could select the other variables
# by supplying the variable names
df_simple %>%
  select(name, age, gender, grade, us_born)

or

# by supplying positions
df_simple %>%
  select(1, 2, 3, 5, 6)

or

# by supplying positions(another way)
df_simple %>%
  select(1:3, 5:6)
  • We could directly drop it
df_simple %>% 
  select(!course) # ! stands for "not"

or

df_simple %>% 
  select(- course)

There are many more options!

mutate()

Problem 1: Suppose we want to find percentage grades(currently grades are given out of 20). How to create such variable? For example, \(\frac{18}{20}\) becomes \(90\).

Solution 1:

Let’s call the new variable grade_p

df_simple %>% 
  mutate(grade_p = grade/20*100)
name age gender course grade us_born grade_p
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE 90
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE 95
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE 60
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE 40
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE 50

Problem 2: Robin Scherbatsky was born in Canada. Generate a new variable, canada: TRUE when name is Robin Scherbatsky; FALSE otherwise.

Solution 2:

We will use case_when(). Note that there are many ways to do it. We will learn about them in the coming weeks.

df_simple %>% 
  mutate(canada = case_when(name == "Robin Scherbatsky" ~ TRUE,
                            name != "Robin Scherbatsky" ~ FALSE))
name age gender course grade us_born canada
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE FALSE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE FALSE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE TRUE
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE FALSE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE FALSE
filter()

Let’s have a glimpse() of our data frame df_simple!

glimpse(df_simple) # you can also use str(df_simple)
## Rows: 5
## Columns: 6
## $ name    <chr> "Ted Mosby", "Marshall Eriksen", "Robin Scherbatsky", "Barney ~
## $ age     <dbl> 46, 41, 38, 47, 46
## $ gender  <chr> "Male", "Male", "Female", "Male", "Female"
## $ course  <chr> "BRM", "BRM", "BRM", "BRM", "BRM"
## $ grade   <dbl> 18, 19, 12, 8, 10
## $ us_born <lgl> TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, TRUE

Problem 1: Suppose we want to find out who are older than 45.

Solution 1:

df_simple %>% 
  filter(age > 45)
name age gender course grade us_born
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE

Problem 2: Suppose we want to consider females only.

Solution 2:

df_simple %>% 
  filter(gender == "Female") # or filter(gender != "Male")
name age gender course grade us_born
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE

Problem 3: Suppose we want to find out who was(were) not born in the US.

Solution 3:

df_simple %>% 
  filter(us_born == FALSE) # filter(us_born != TRUE)
name age gender course grade us_born
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE

Logical Operators:

Code Description
< less than
<= less than or equal to
> greater than
>= greater than or equal to
== exactly equal to
!= not equal to
!x not x
x | y x or y
x & y x and y
summarise()

Problem 1: Suppose we want to find mean and median grades.

Solution:

df_simple %>% 
  summarise(mean_grade = mean(grade),
            median_grade = median(grade))
mean_grade median_grade
13.4 12

NOTE: summarise creates a new data frame (of course, to store it, you need to ask your best friend – the assignment operator!)

Problem 2: Suppose we want to find mean and median grades by gender.

Solution:

To do so, we need to use group_by() before summarise().

df_simple %>% 
  group_by(gender) %>% 
  summarise(mean_grade = mean(grade),
            median_grade = median(grade))
gender mean_grade median_grade
Female 11 11
Male 15 18

Useful Functions:

Function What it Calculates
mean() Mean
median() Median
var() Variance
sd() Standard deviation
min() Minimum
max() Maximum
n() Number of Observations
arrange()

arrange() orders the rows of a data frame by the values of selected column(s).

  • use desc() or - for descending order

Example (single column): sort name

df_simple %>% 
  arrange(name)
name age gender course grade us_born
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE 
df_simple %>% 
  arrange(desc(name))
name age gender course grade us_born
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE

Example (multiple columns): sort gender then sort name

df_simple %>% 
  arrange(gender, name) # try using desc()
name age gender course grade us_born
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE

Unlike other dplyr verbs, arrange() largely ignores grouping; you need to explicitly mention grouping variables (or use .by_group = TRUE)

  • Suppose our data frame df_simple is grouped by gender
    • df_simple <- df_simple %>% group_by(gender)
df_simple <- df_simple %>% 
  group_by(gender)
glimpse(df_simple)
## Rows: 5
## Columns: 6
## Groups: gender [2]
## $ name    <chr> "Ted Mosby", "Marshall Eriksen", "Robin Scherbatsky", "Barney ~
## $ age     <dbl> 46, 41, 38, 47, 46
## $ gender  <chr> "Male", "Male", "Female", "Male", "Female"
## $ course  <chr> "BRM", "BRM", "BRM", "BRM", "BRM"
## $ grade   <dbl> 18, 19, 12, 8, 10
## $ us_born <lgl> TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, TRUE, TRUE
  • df_simple %>% arrange(name) will not take grouping into account
df_simple %>% 
  arrange(name)
name age gender course grade us_born
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE
  • you need to use df_simple_grouped %>% arrange(name, .by_group = TRUE )
df_simple %>% 
  arrange(name, .by_group = TRUE)
name age gender course grade us_born
Lily Aldrin 46 Female BRM 10 TRUE
Robin Scherbatsky 38 Female BRM 12 FALSE
Barney Stinson 47 Male BRM 8 TRUE
Marshall Eriksen 41 Male BRM 19 TRUE
Ted Mosby 46 Male BRM 18 TRUE

To ungroup, use ungroup()

  • df_simple %>% ungroup() will do the job

Exercise

The file, dplyr-csv.csv, we are going to use has the following variables:

ITEM Info
5601 Ticker Symbol
6001 Company Name
6026 Nation
7210 Market Capitalization
7220 Common Equity
7230 Total Assets
7240 Net Sales or Revenues
7250 Net Income

Task 1: Read the csv file dplyr-csv.csv, store it as df_raw

Task 2: Keep the variables year_, ITEM5601, ITEM6001, ITEM6026, ITEM7250; store it as df_small

Task 3: Rename the variables as given below; store it as df_renamed

New Name Old Name
year year
ticker ITEM5601
cname ITEM6001
country ITEM6026
net_income ITEM7250

Task 4: Mutate the following variables; store it as df_mutated

  • portugal: TRUE when country is Portugal; FALSE otherwise
  • net_income_m: express net_income in million USD i.e. net_income/1e6 (note: 1e6 = 1,000,000)

Task 5: Keep only Portuguese firms; store it as df_pt

Task 6: Grouped by year, find the following statistics

  • mean_m: mean net_income_m
  • median_m: net_income_m
  • n: number of observations

Hint: you need to use na.rm = TRUE

You should get the following output:

year mean_m median_m n
2017 52.01716 7.781347 78
2018 80.62462 8.881793 73
2019 89.25249 19.674088 71
